Title: the vartabedian conundrum

Scene: Leonard’s bedroom. Leonard and Steph have just had sex.
Outside Penny’s apartment. Sheldon has his laptop. He knocks three times, the presses a button and an electronic voice says “Penny”. He does this three times.
Steph: I don’t see anything at all, Sheldon.
Yup, there’s no inflammation at all, Sheldon.
I Seriously doubt it.
Well, you know, if it is from a swirly, there’s something I can do. Okay, circle, circle, dot, dot, now you have a cootie shot! I’m going to bed
Hi, Sheldon.
He did very nicely.
Uh, hello.
Uh-huh. And, and, and you are?
Really?
I haven’t heard a thing about you. Leonard? Why haven’t I heard a thing about this woman who lives across the hall and comes into your apartment in the morning in her underwear?
Well, it was very nice meeting you.
And I’ll see you tonight?
Bye.
Sheldon, what are you doing here?
Where did you get the stethoscope and the blood pressure cuff?
Thank you.
I’m kinda busy here, Sheldon.
A cardiac stress test, a full body MRI, an electromyogram, a CBC, baseline glucose, upper GI?
Go home, Sheldon.
Oh, no.
You were right. Your larynx is terribly inflamed. I mean, I’ve never seen anything like it.
You’re going to need to stop talking immediately.
Du-du-du-du! Immediately.
Oh, hi, honey.
I just performed a Sheldonectomy.
Gotcha.
Oh-oh. Do we need to talk or do we “need to talk”?
Okay, why don’t you just tell me what it is you have to tell me?
And?
Well, yeah, but scary good, right?
Uh-huh.
Of course honey why don’t you tell me what it is you’re feeling?
Okay, how about this? How about I tell you what I’m feeling?
Why not?
I think that’s for swimming.
Yeah.
I’m sorry, I totally interrupted you. What were you saying?
Oh, God, here comes the speech.

I really like you, but maybe we should spend a little less time together ‘cause I need my space but I’ll call you on Tuesday, and then you never call me so I call you, but you don’t call me back and then when I run into you at the coffee shop you pretend like you’ve been having problems with your voice mail and I know that you’re lying, but I pretend like I don’t care even though I’m dying inside!
Oh. Oh, good! ‘Cause I really like you, too.
Sheldon: Well, you’re the doctor, but I am constantly hearing this annoying sound.
Is it a high-frequency whistle?
Then it must be a tumour.
Is that possible? I used to get those all the time. Even in church.
It’s not enough that she mocks me, but that isn’t even the correct procedure for a cootie shot.
How is it imaginary that I keep hearing an octave above Middle C? Is that imaginary? I don’t think so.
Leonard, there’s one more thing. Under Article One, Section Three of our Roommate Agreement, I’m calling an emergency meeting.
Leonard moves the meeting not occur. Is there a second? None heard, the motion fails. I’d like to begin the meeting by congratulating you on the progress in your relationship with Dr. Stephanie.
That being said, we have to discuss the implementation of the agreed upon “cohabitation” rider which has been activated now that the two of you are living together.
You initialed it. See? L.H., L.H., L.H.

Hmm, yes, you did. Now, to review the following provisions are hereby activated. In the refrigerator, as opposed to us having two separate shelves and one communal shelf, the three of us now get individual shelves and the door becomes communal. Next, apartment vacuuming shall be increased from two to three times a week to accommodate the increased accumulation of dead skin cells. Third,the bathroom schedule. Now, I’m given to understand women have different needs, so, we’ll have to discuss that.

At least take this with you. Look, and have Stephanie initial here, here, here, here and here. This states that she does not now nor does she intend to play a percussive or brass instrument. Sure it sounds like a tumor pressing on the auditory nerve.
It’s not a big deal. We have latex gloves.
Good morning, Dr. Stephanie. I trust Leonard satisfied you sexually last night.
I heard you ask it over and over. How is it inappropriate for me to ask it once?
See? She’s not offended. And now you finally have an answer.
In Leonard’s defence, it wasn’t for lack of trying.
You’re welcome, Leonard.
Really? I have never once been invited to have cereal with Mrs. Vartabedian.
What could I possibly have done to offend Mrs. Vartabedian?
Oh, she is. She’s terrific, and she’s proving to be a valuable roommate.
Like hippies.
Do I have to pull out the paperwork again?
Hang on. 130 over 80. A little high. We can attribute that to the stress of sneaking past the security desk.

My aunt Marion gave them to me for my 12th birthday. She thought if I failed at theoretical physics that I should have a trade to fall back on. And by the way, the blood pressure cuff is called a sphygmomanometer.
Didn’t they teach you that in medical school?
I understand. All I need is for you to authorize these tests.
Oh, and an exploratory laparoscopy. Last time I had hiccups, it felt like my diaphragm was just going through the motions.
Can I at least have the upper GI? I already drank the barium!
Wha??
I knew it! What do I do?
For how…
Leonard: Me, too.
No, it’s more of a relentless, narcissistic drone.
Maybe it’s a lingering bacterial infection from all those childhood toilet swirlies.
Okay, I’ll be right in.
Do you understand that Stephanie’s not here to treat your imaginary ailments?
Good night.
No, you’re not.
Thank you.
We’re not living together.
That’s absurd.
Wait, I only initialed it because I never thought it would happen! I initialed another clause naming you my sidekick in case I get superpowers.
I’m going to bed.
No, absolutely not.
I don’t care what the symptoms are, my girlfriend is not going to give you a prostate exam.
Oh come on! Sheldon, we don’t ask questions like that.
She’s heard about you because we’re, you know, involved and you haven’t heard about her because… I never slept with her, I swear!
Thank you, Sheldon.

Look, I’m just saying, um, Penny is one of our many neighbours, you know, and in our building, neighbours come and go, it’s very casual, no dress code. In fact, some mornings I’ll just mosey down to the third floor in my pyjamas and have cereal with Mrs. Vartabedian.
She doesn’t like you. Um, well, uh, you have a gall bladder to remove and I have to get in the shower and Penny has clothes to put on, so…
Okay, bye-bye.
Why do I feel like I’m the one that just got the prostate exam?
We’re not living together.
We’re not living together.
How could I not be sure?
Don’t you think if a woman was living with me I’d be the first one to know about it?
We’re not living together.
We’re not living together.
Uh, the big dog is Goofy, and the older couple with the mouse ears , I have no idea. We’re not living together!
We’re not… Where’s my Bat Signal?
I did. It was right here. She must’ve… Oh, my God, we’re living together.
Yeah, Stephanie got them for me.
Actually, I think it’s more of wool, fire ant blend.
It is actually. In fact, I gave it a lot of thought and I decided it was time for us to live together.
At least I have an egg. What do you have?
So, go hit on her.
I don’t care what you guys think, Stephanie and I are very happy living together. I will give either of you 20 dollars, right now to trade pants with me.
Oh, good. Do you have any fabric softener?
No, the pants that Stephanie got me.
Are you sure?
Oh, no. I wish you’d told me that sooner.
No, everything’s fine.
Yeah. It’s wonderful. Okay, maybe this whole living together happened kind of suddenly, but it’s fine, it’s great.
Are you sure? That doesn’t sound right.
No that doesn’t sound right either.
Yeah, I could say something like that to her. I’ll go do that. Thank you.
You have a really good grasp on this. Maybe you could talk to her?
No, but that’s okay. I’ll go talk to her. Want to come with?
Hey.
Sheldon. (He waves) What’s going on?
Careful, if you don’t get it all, it’ll only come back worse.
Listen, we need to talk.
I don’t know what that means.
Okay, um, well, look, it’s just that things between you and me have been going pretty quick.
It’s just a little scary.
Sure, when is scary not good? But, okay, um, I have feelings, right?
Okay, and it’s perfectly okay to express those feelings, right?
Okay, well, I ju… I think it’s important to remember that we move at a pace that is our speed and… oh, shoot, I had it!
What’s that? Really? Right now?
I just ate, aren’t you supposed to wait an hour?
Oh, okay. I just hope I don’t get cramps.
Hey.
Thank you.
Good.
Well, um, on one level, really, really well.
Not specifically, but, uh, I did tell her that I had feelings.
And then the, the subject got changed somehow.
Um, little bit. (She looks at her watch) What?
Yeah, yeah it’s all good. Everything’s going to work out. One way or another.
Really?
Huh.
Nothing, just rethinking my whole life. Okay, here’s the thing, I’m afraid that if I ask her to move out, she’ll just dump me.
Very comforting. Okay, so what do I say to her?
I really like you, but I want to see how things go with Mark?
Oh, right, yeah, um, so, Stephanie, here’s the thing. I really like you.
What speech?
No! No, no! I wasn’t going to say any of that. I was just going to say, I really like you.
Terrific.
Hey.
Yeah, Stephanie got it for me. It’s kind of fun.

Yeah, yeah, that’s the fun part. We’re also getting new curtains for my bedroom, and a dust ruffle, and a duvet, and I don’t even know what a duvet is but I’m pretty sure if I did I wouldn’t want one, but every time I talk to her about moving out she cries and we have sex.
Isn’t that kind of cowardly?
Sold. “I think it would be better for our relationship if you moved back to your place.” There. It’s done.
Yeah, good for me. I’ll never have sex again. (Phone buzzes) I was wrong. See ya.
Sheldon: I beg to disagree. \u201cA girl: all the weekends of a given month plus three weeknights.
Penny: Hi! Stephanie, right?
I’m Penny, I live across the hall. I’ve heard a lot about you.
Mm-hmm.
Nice to finally meet you, too.
So, that’s Stephanie, huh?
You know, she seems very nice.
Roommate? You guys are living together?
Are you sure?
Well, let’s find out.
Oh, sweetie, you’d be the last one to know about it. (Looking through his wardrobe) Hmm, cute dresses. I bet this looks great on you!
Okay, hmm, scented candles, fuzzy slippers, ooh, floral bed sheets?
Okay, moving on. Now, who are these guys at Disney World?
You’re going to go down swinging, huh? All right, well, we got your body lotion, your InStyle Magazine, your jewellery box.
You have a Bat Signal?
Really? What was your first clue?
Oh hey.
Yeah, sure. What are you washing? A crocodile?
Oh, sweetie, you can’t machine wash these. They’ll be ruined.
Absolutely.
Are you guys having problems?
Really?
Okay, Leonard, honey, you know, if you’re uncomfortable with the way things are going, you’re allowed to say something.
Believe me, your feelings are just as important as hers.
Just tell her you need the relationship to move at a pace that you both are comfortable with.
Sure.
You’re kidding, right?
Go! Wow.
Hey. Oh, I put your clothes in the dryer.
Your pants are ruined.
So, how did the talk with Stephanie go?
So, you told her you wanted to slow things down?
Good, good. And then what?
You had sex, didn’t you?
Nothing. Okay, well, it sounds like things are going to work out.
Come on, Leonard, you are entitled to try and make things go the way you want them to.
Yes, you don’t always have to go along with what the woman wants.
What?
Well, it’s a chance you have to take. I mean, look, if it’s meant to be, it’ll be.
I don’t know. I mean, what have women said to you when they wanted to slow a relationship down?
Yeah, that’ll slow it down.
Okay?
Okay, let me check.
Hiney?
Howard: So, the girlfriend’s buying clothes for you, huh? Sounds serious.
Uh, Leonard, huge mistake. There’s a whole buffet of women out there and you’re just standing in the corner eating the same devilled egg over and over again.
A veritable smorgasbord of potential sexual partners. See the blonde over there? I can hit on her and you can’t.
You know, if you can’t talk to her, why don’t you just text her?
Raj: Too bad, ’cause she was checking you out before.
Of course not. Look at her.
It’s got a big bird on it, dude.
You’re lucky. With me, it’s usually the other way around.
It’s true, but on the other hand you are wearing a bird sweater.
Computer voice: We’re out of herbal tea. Do you have any?
Some hiney would be nice, too.
